note: Accessible, readable translation with useful notes, basic bibliography, and four maps.
title: Arrian’s Campaign of Alexander
Alexander the Great: Historical Sources in Translation

Following a description of sources, lost as well as extant, excerpts from the sources are organized by specific categories such as the Macedonian background, the army and war, Alexander and the Macedonians

note: Description of the known, now lost, accounts of Alexander, from those of official historians through reminiscences, antiquarians, and purported works such as Alexander’s last plans.
title: The Lost Histories of Alexander the Great
The Ephemerides of Alexander’s Expedition
The History of Alexander the Great I : A Translation of the Extant Fragments
Reconstruction of the day-book accounts of Alexander’s campaign thought to have been kept but whose genuineness is doubted by many
Legends of Alexander the Great
Collection of legendary reports, such as a conversation between Alexander and Brahman leaders and a letter to Aristotle on India, that we wish were genuine
Alexander the Great II: Sources and Studies
Examination of sources with appendices on major issues such as the author’s view that Alexander was motivated by a belief in the brotherhood of mankind
Alexander the Great in Fact and Fiction
Articles resulting from a 1997 symposium with the aim of identifying distortion and myth-making in accounts of Alexander

note: Also valuable for its excellent aids: dramatis personae; glossary; sturdy, annotated bibliography.
title: Alexander the Great:The Hunt for a New Past
Readable account resulting from the author’s goal of doing justice to the achievement of its subject, including some probing into Alexander’s psyche, while appreciating the limited evidence

note: An account of Alexander’s generalship by a modern commander.
title: The Generalship of Alexander the Great
Alexander of Macedon 356–323 B.C.: A Historical Biography

Reprint of the 1970 study that has rightly retained readership for its completeness, beginning with Philip and ending with reflection on the mythification that set in after Alexander’s death. Readers will appreciate the full references and bibliography as well as the engaging style that marks all of Green’s writing
Alexander: Destiny and Myth
La destinée d’un myth

Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press. The original title more aptly defines the goal of the author in tracking the evolution of legends of Alexander, including the mythic elements. Following an account of Alexander’s campaign, discussion turns to specific aspects of the man and his legacy
A Manuscript found in the Portfolio of Las Cases, containing Maxims and Observations of Napoleon, collected during the last two years of his Residence at St
Alexander the Great II: Sources and Studies
Alexander the Great
The Natural Resources of Early Macedonia
Philip II, Alexander the Great and the Macedonian Heritage. Lanham and New
Useful summary of the physical nature of Macedonia by a scholar who has a wide range of publications on ancient Macedonia to his credit

note: Bibliographic notes as well as more standard bibliographic references are very helpful.
title: In the Shadow of Olympus: The Emergence of Macedon

Impressive account of Macedonian developments from their misty beginnings through the achievements of Philip II. The author tackles all of the thorny issues of this subject including the identities of the dead in the Vergina tombs

note: a focus that involves the philosopher’s links with Macedon and particular Macedonians.
title: Aristotle and the Foreign Policy of Macedonia
The author has devoted much of his career in scholarship to Aristotle. Included in his interests are the “historical Aristotle
Aux Origines du Miracle Grec
An excellent resource for developments in northern Greece – Thessaly, Macedon, and Epiros – tracing the process of settlement, organization and use of space, and population size and dispersal
Vergina: Wandering through the Archaeological Site. Athens: Ministry of Culture. Compact but beautifully illustrated guide to the site with succinct commentary on the excavation and its findings
Early Macedonia
Even before such finds as those at Vergina, Charles Edson penetrated the nature of its early culture in this revealing account
A History of Macedonia (tr. by C. Errington of Geschichte Makedoniens
Berkeley and Los

note: of three describes the historical geography of Macedonia and its prehistory, carrying the story to 550 bc.
title: A History of Macedonia I: Historical Geography and Prehistory

Dropped behind the lines of the German occupiers of Greece to aid the resistance, Nicholas Hammond became intimately familiar with the land. Macedonia was a major object of his attention through a long and distinguished career

The Miracle that was Macedonia. London and New York: Sidgwick and Jackson and St Martin’s Press. Far more compact account of ancient Macedonian history intended for a wider readership than the previous or subsequent books

collection-title: in the series, the authors describe the development of the state and its difficulties in surviving
title: A History of Macedonia II: 550–336 BC
Pella: Capital of Macedonians. Athens: Ministry of Culture. Another publication by the Greek Ministry of Culture in format and quality akin to that on Vergina, cited above
Athenians, Macedonians, and the Origins of the Macedonian Royal House
Makes a case against the tradition that argued a Greek origin for the Argead rulers of Macedon. Acceptance of such a tradition, however, may have been useful for the Macedonian kings
Archelaus the Philhellene
Succession and Regency in Classical Macedonia
That priority of succession was given to the ruling king’s first-born son is the argument of this important scholar of Macedonia

container-title: Concise overview of Philip’s role in the economic development of Macedonia
title: Philip’s Innovations in Macedonian Economy

note: another by H. Dell, cited below under “Military momentum,” two contributions by G. Cawkwell on Philip’s relations with the Greeks, plus nine other essays. The volume is nicely illustrated, and includes useful but not overly extensive notes and bibliography.
title: Philip of Macedon
Collection of articles by major scholars on various aspects of Philip II. Included are the Charles Edson essay “Early Macedonia,” cited above under “Macedonia
Greek Diplomatic Tradition and the Corinthian League of Philip of Macedon

Makes a case for Philip’s use of traditional Greek treaties and diplomacy to create in the League of Corinth an organization that would be acceptable to the Greeks, while allowing him to become its hegemon as well as the leader of the campaign against Persia
The Settlements of Philip II in 338 bc
Careful study of the settlements orchestrated by Philip following the Macedonian victory at Chaironeia that provided the basis for the creation of the League of Corinth

note: Description of Philip’s successes within the fluid alliance structure of the fourth century.
publisher: Oxford University Press for the University of Hull
title: Eclipse of the Leading Powers and the Rise of Macedon. In Ryder, Koine Eirene
Alexander, Philip, and the Macedonian Background

Brill’s Companion to Alexander the Great. Leiden and Boston: Brill, 69–98. Persuasive argument that the adjective “great” is appropriate to Philip in light of his accomplishments as Macedonian king, commander of the army, and statesman in his wider dealings with other fourth-century states
Olympias
Women and Monarchy in Macedonia

container-title: Macedonian history. Not only do individual figures gain personalities but the change in women’s status over time is carefully demonstrated
title: Olympias: Mother of Alexander the Great
Elizabeth Carney is the main source for serious study of the role of women, particularly royal women

container-title: Classical Contributions: Studies in Honour of M
title: Philip and Olympias 337/36
Historical Perceptions of Greco-Macedonian Ethnicity in the Hellenistic Age

note: was occurring even earlier.
title: While the focus of the discussion is post-Alexander, the author perceives, rightly I believe, the importance of hellenization in the fourth century. I would argue that the “blurring of lines

container-title: Macedonia and Greece in Late Classical and Early Hellenistic Times
note: for Macedonia.
title: Greeks and Macedonians

Professor Badian has published extensively and insightfully on Macedonian matters. In this essay he argues that Macedonians were not thought by others to be Greek, nor did they consider themselves to be Greek. A claim to Greek origins may have originated in the fifth or early fourth century, “a sorry time

container-title: Transitions to Empire: Essays in Greco-Roman History, 360–146 B.C., in Honor of E. Badian
title: Greeks and Macedonians in the Age of Alexander: The Source Traditions
Origins, Ethnicity, and Institutions

Regina Books. In this and numerous other publications, Professor Borza solidly defends the view that Greek and Macedonian ethnicities differ from one another in most respects: language, cultural practices, material culture, societal organization, economic way of life

note: While Greeks might have passed through Macedonia, they continued south and produced a different way of life.
title: Imagining Macedonia in Prehistory, ca. 1900–1930

In an unusual, but valuable, approach to the issues of Macedonian identity, the author maintains that the view of Macedonians as the antithesis of the Greeks emerged when research in the region expanded during the early twentieth century
Contested Ethnicities: Perceptions of Macedon within Evolving Definitions of Greek Identity
Useful picture of the ambiguities between ethnicity and the heroic claims of peoples in northern Greece upon the expanding colonization from southern Greece

note: Chapter 3, part 5, discusses the influence of Greek culture, and part 6 treats the institutions of the Macedonians and their neighbors.
title: A History of Macedonia II: 550–336 BC

note: Evidence for Greek linguistic elements in Macedonia. Greek view of Macedonians
title: MAKEDONIKA KAI OMHRIKA GLWSSA

note: Handy English translation of important orations.
title: Greek Orations
Die Fragmente der Griechischen Historiker

container-title: View of Persia shared by Greeks and Macedonians
title: Demosthenes and Aeschines. Harmondsworth: Penguin. Translations of the differing perspectives exemplified by Demosthenes, the bitter foe of Philip, and Aischines, who found traits to admire
Why did Philip and Alexander Launch a War against the Persian Empire?

I was elated and relieved to read this essay by a valued colleague and friend who argues the genuineness of common grounds for the campaign against Persia by the League of Corinth under its Macedonian hegemon
Aegean Greece in the Fourth Century. Leiden and Boston: Brill. Full account beginning with the end of the Peloponnesian War and ending in 336 with the death of Philip II
The Greek State

Although published in 1960, this account of the Greek state remains a standard source for the defining features of the polis as well as its structure and functions. A chapter on types of federations is valuable for developments of the fourth century and beyond
The Shotgun Method: The Demography of the Classical Polis

One of many recent studies of the Greek polis by one of the most productive scholars on the subject, both through his individual publications and through the Copenhagen Polis Centre over which he presides

container-title: Philip of Macedon. Athens: Ekdotike Athenon SA
title: Philip and Macedonia’s Northern Neighbors
Deftly and succinctly pictures the nature of the peoples inhabiting the northern extension of the Greek sphere and their interactions with reference to their role in Macedonian history

container-title: and chapter 4 explores the second military revolution
title: Wars of the Ancient Greeks
Chapter 3 of this account by a noted military historian discusses the great wars (490–362

container-title: Important essay on an essential ingredient of the success of Philip and Alexander. Subordinates
title: Macedonian Military Machinery and its Designers under Philip and Alexander

publisher: Research Centre for Greek and Roman Antiquity, National Hellenic Research Foundation
title: The Antigonids, Heracles, and Beroea. Harvard Studies in Classical Philology 45, 213–46. Argues the view that Antigonos came from Beroea, a stance not widely accepted although recent evidence strengthens the case
Ancient Beroea: Prosopography and Society

container-title: Part II discusses careers within the military. It updates and serves
note: for non-German readers, the purpose of H. Berve’s two-volume work Das Alexanderreich auf prosopographischer Grundlage (Munich: Beck, 1925–6). Persia
title: The Marshals of Alexander’s Empire
Provides an essential tool in a study of Alexander’s subordinates. Part I treats “Old Guard,” “New Men,” “Casualities of the Succession” and “Boyhood Friends

note: 2005) and Alexander the Great: The Heroic Ideal (French edition 1987; English edition, London:Thames and Hudson, 1996).
title: From Cyrus to Alexander: A History of the Persian Empire
Daniels of Histoire de l’Empire perse

Winona Lake, IN: Eisenbrauns. Fullest (1,196 pages), best-documented account available, unlikely to be bettered. The author does not see serious difficulties in the empire even after Alexander had entered Anatolia. Briant has also written two accounts of Alexander: an excellent, very concise study for the French Que sais-je? series, Alexandre Le Grand

note: See esp. chapter 10, “The End of the Achaemenids: Macedonia and Persia.”
title: The Greek Wars: The Failure of Persia
Useful summary that discloses several serious flaws in the empire, such as the internal disorder that often accompanied accessions
The Persian Empire
Account of Achaemenid Persia from its emergence through its defeat at the hands of the Macedonian army of Alexander; far more concise than Briant
Greeks and Persians in the Fourth Century: A Study in Cultural Contacts before Alexander
Valuable examinations of the cultural relationships of the peoples facing one another across the Aegean Sea during the critical decades of the rise of Macedonia
Description of the education of Kyros the Great that preserves information about Achaemenid culture
Memory and the Mediterranean

Magnificent account of the flow of history in cultures connected by the Mediterranean Sea from prehistory to the Roman creation of its empire, by the man who had been identified as one of the greatest historians of the twentieth century
Guns, Germs and Steel:The Fates of Human Societies
